newsitem.title: GERMANY: Sustained protests seen against gene-soy.
newsitem.headline: Sustained protests seen against gene-soy.

text.p: European protests against genetically modified U.S. soybeans mark the start of a sustained campaign, U.S. consumer activist Jeremy Rifkin said during a visit to Germany on Tuesday.

"This global boycott will not go away, it won't be just a matter of a few demonstrations," Rifkin said by telephone from his hotel in Rendsburg in Schleswig-Holstein state, where he was due to attend a conference on non-profit business.
The German section of environmental group Greenpeace will protest at the arrival of a ship carrying 44,600 tonnes of new crop U.S. soybeans in Hamburg tonight.
The cargo may contain the new gene-modified beans, which are resistant to a weedkiller and were developed by U.S. firm Monsanto. Opponents cite unknown health risks.
Rifkin leads a Washington-based consumer pressure group and has been working to organise a worldwide boycott of genetically engineered corn and soybeans.
He said brokers in the U.S. were now offering certified gene-free soybeans at a premium.
"The first such ship will leave Duluth on Tuesday or Wednesday but I don't have details," he said.
European consumers had agreed to pay higher prices but it would take some time to put sufficiently large cargoes together.
